title: Why do song phrases sound more pleasing when going up in scale? Are there any examples of songs where the song is going down in pitch frequently? - Quora

response.answer_text: What an interesting question. I have two John Lennon songs for you. In “I Am The Walrus", the verses are all descending. Then the chorus steadily ascends to its proclamation: I am the Walrus, GooGoo Ga Joob. “Working Class Hero" has five phrases, which it repeats. The first line ends where it started (From the moment you're born, they make you feel small.) Line 2 goes up slightly (By giving you no time instead of it all.) Line 3 descends (till the pain is so big, you feel nothing at all.) The first line of the chorus starts on higher note than the verses, then descends. ( A working class hero is something to be.) Then it repeats. The last line of the chorus begins on the same note as the first verse, rises three notes, then descends to the lowest note of the song. (If you want to be a hero, then just follow me.) The predominantly descending phrases underscore the depressing message in the lyrics. Why does music affect emotions this way, you ask? I can't tell you. It just does. Going up uplifts us. Going down is a downer. I don't know if Working Class Hero is the best example of this, but it's the best one I can think of. I'm curious what other people will come up with.
